Example

  1. Write \(3+4+5+6+7+8+9\) using sigma notation.
  2. Write \(4+9+16+\cdots+100\) using sigma notation.
Solution
  1. There are 7 terms so we could use \(\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^7\). We want the first term to be 3, so we should add up \(n+2\) each time, i.e. \[ \sum_{n=1}^7 (n+2) = 3+4+5+6+7+8+9. \]
  2. Note that these are all squares, so of the form \(n^2\). We start with \(n=2\) and end up with \(n=10\), so we have \[ \sum_{n=2}^{10} n^2 = 4+9+16+\cdots+100. \] What if we wanted to start with \(n=1\) instead? We would also need to change the end number and the formula: \[ \sum_{n=1}^9 (n+1)^2 = 4+9+16+\cdots+100. \] As this example shows, there is no unique way to write a sum using sigma notation.
